HistoryModule#

class HistoryModule(step_time: float, history_len: float)[source]#

Bases: DimensionalModule

Module which keeps track of previous attribute values.

Parameters:

  • step_time (float) – length of time between stored values in history.

  • history_len (float) – length of time over which prior values are stored.

Raises:

  • ValueError – step time must be positive.

  • ValueError – history length must be nonnegative.

deregister_constrained(name: str)[source]#

Sets a registered buffer or parameter as unconstrained.

Parameters:

name (str) – attribute to constrain.

Note

This implies the attribute will not have its history tracked. Because this is implemented using DimensionalModule constraints, it will also be freed of any other constraints.

property dt: float#

Length of time between stored values in history.

Parameters:

value (float) – new time step length.

Returns:

length of the time step.

Return type:

float

Note

In the same units as self.hlen.

history(name: str, offset: int = 1, latest_first=True) → Tensor[source]#

Retrieves the recorded history of a constrained attribute.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • offset (int, optional) – window index offset, number of tick() calls back. Defaults to 1.

  • latest_first (bool, optional) – if the most recent sample should be at the zeroth index. Defaults to False.

Returns:

value of the attribute at every observed time.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

property hlen: float#

Length of time over which prior values are stored.

Parameters:

value (float) – new length of the history to store.

Returns:

length of the history.

Return type:

float

Note

In the same units as self.dt.

property hsize: int#

Number of stored time slices for each history tensor.

Returns:

length of the history, in units of time.

Return type:

float

latest(name: str, offset: int = 1) → Tensor[source]#

Retrieves the most recent slice of a constrained attribute.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • offset (int, optional) – window index offset, number of tick() calls back. Defaults to 1.

Raises:

AttributeError – specified name is not a constrained buffer or parameter.

Returns:

most recent slice of the tensor selected.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Note

By default, offset is set to 1. This is the correct configuration to use under normal circumstances where pushto() is used for element insertion. Also this is useful for when tick() is called after a call to insert() and before select(). This should be set to 0 if tick() has not been called since the last insert().

pushto(name: str, data: Tensor) → None[source]#

Inserts a slice at the current time into a constrained attribute and advances to the next time.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • data (torch.Tensor) – data to insert.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – cannot push to an uninitialized buffer or parameter.

  • RuntimeError – data has an incompatible shape with buffer or parameter.

  • AttributeError – specified name is not a constrained buffer or parameter.

register_constrained(name: str)[source]#

Sets a registered buffer or parameter as constrained.

Parameters:

name (str) – attribute to constrain.

Note

This implies the attribute will have its history tracked, and therefore must have a final dimension of size hsize. Because this is implemented using DimensionalModule constraints, it must meet any other constraints that have been added.

reset(name: str, data: Any) → None[source]#

Resets a constrained attribute to some value or values.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • data (Any) – data to insert.

Raises:

RuntimeError – cannot reset an uninitialized buffer or parameter.

select(name: str, time: float | Tensor, interpolation: Interpolation, *, tolerance: float = 1e-07, offset: int = 1) → Tensor[source]#

Selects elements of a constrained attribute based on prior time.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • time (float | torch.Tensor) – time before present to select from.

  • interpolation (Interpolate) – method to interpolate between discrete time steps.

  • tolerance (float, optional) – maximum difference in time from a discrete sample to onsider it at the same time as that sample. Defaults to 1e-7.

  • offset (int, optional) – window index offset, number of tick() calls back. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

interpolated tensor selected at a prior time.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Shape

time:

\(N_0 \times \cdots \times [D]\)

return:

\(N_0 \times \cdots \times [D]\)

Where:

  • \(N_0, \ldots\) are the dimensions of the constrained tensor.

  • \(D\) is the number of times for each value to select.

Note

The constraints on the shape of time are not enforced, and follows the underlying logic of torch.gather().

Note

By default, offset is set to 1. This is the correct configuration to use under normal circumstances where pushto() is used for element insertion. Also this is useful for when tick() is called after a call to insert() and before select(). This should be set to 0 if tick() has not been called since the last insert().

Note

The argument interpolate is a function which takes in four arguments, as follows.

  • tensor: nearest observed state before the selected time.

  • tensor: nearest observed state after the selected time.

  • tensor: time after the “before state” for which results should be produced.

  • float: difference in time between the before and after state.

It must return a tensor of values interpolated between the samples at the two times. Some functions which meet the Interpolation type are included in the library.

Note

If time is a scalar and is within tolerance of an integer index, then a slice will be returned without ever attempting interpolation.

If time is a tensor, interpolation will be called regardless, and the time passed into the interpolation call will be set to either 0 or self.dt. Interpolation results are then overwritten with exact values before returning.

tick(name: str) → None[source]#

Manually increment the time, by the step time, for a specified attribute.

Parameters:

name (str) – attribute for which time should be incremented.

update(name: str, data: Tensor, offset: int = 0) → None[source]#

Updates time slice of a tensor at a specific index.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • data (torch.Tensor) – data to insert into history.

  • offset (int, optional) – number of steps before present to update. Defaults to 0.
